titleInfo.title: Adult Attachment, Mindfulness, and Individual Anxiety
titleInfo.subTitle: A Longitudinal Mediation Approach

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.abstract: Insecure attachment styles have been linked to a higher risk of anxiety and affective disorders. This link is further underscored by the high prevalence of adults experiencing anxiety symptoms. While past research has suggested that mindfulness may elucidate the well-established association between adult attachment orientations and individual anxiety symptoms, there remains a limited understanding within the context of romantic relationships. Grounded in Family Systems Theory (FST) and Attachment Theory (AT), this longitudinal study explored the associations between attachment orientations and individual anxiety as mediated by mindfulness. The research aimed to elucidate temporal associations among these variables in 105 heterosexual couples undergoing systemic therapy over eight treatment sessions, at three time points (T1 = Session 1, T2 = Session 4, T3 = Session 8). Direct and indirect path analysis, employed via the Actor-Partner Interdependence Mediation Model (APIMeM), suggested that there were significant intra- and interpersonal direct associations. The female partner's anxious attachment at T1 was negatively associated with her mindfulness at T2. The male partner's anxious attachment at T1 was negatively associated with the female partner's mindfulness at T2. Females' anxious and avoidant attachment at T1 was negatively associated with male partners' anxiety at T3, suggesting a possible adaptive and relational efficacy feature of insecure attachment, in which anxiously or avoidantly attached females at the start of therapy had partners who exhibited low levels of individual anxiety by session 8. Neither male nor female mindfulness at T2 mediated the association between attachment anxiety and avoidance at T1 and individual anxiety at T3, intra- or interpersonally, which suggested a continued need to examine the temporal associations of mindfulness in romantic relationships, particularly in clinical contexts. This study expanded upon existing research that highlights interdependent internal processes in romantic couples and affirmed previous findings indicating that mindfulness is connected to the dynamics of romantic relationships. Findings have implications for research development through integrating FST and AT to examine temporal associations of internal processes in romantic relationships. Additionally, there are clinical implications for the practice of marriage and family therapy (MFT) through the use of attachment and mindfulness-based strategies to treat intra- and interpersonal processes observed in couples therapy.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
anxiety, anxious attachment, avoidant attachment, couples therapy, longitudinal, mindfulness
Qiong Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Shengli Dong, University Representative; Lenore M. McWey, Committee Member; Jonathan G. Kimmes, Committee Member.
